title: Paris police attacker 'heard voices' before deadly knife rampage
text:

The knife attacker who stabbed to death four at Paris' police headquarters on Thursday had suffered a "fit of dementia" in which he "heard voices", his wife has told investigators.

Mickael Harpon 45, had worked in the IT department of the closely-guarded police intelligence unit for 20 years.

He went on the rampage at Thursday lunchtime, killing his female superior, two other officers and an administrative worker with a ceramic kitchen knife before being shot dead by a policeman in the courtyard of the building - a stone's throw from Notre-Dame cathedral.

Two others were injured in the frenzied attack but there lives are no longer in danger.

Police are searching for clues as to the motive, combing his home and personal computer in Gonesse, neart Roissy Charles de Gaulle airport northeast of Paris.

The attacker's wife told investigators her husband, who had a severe hearing disability, had displayed "unusual and agitated behaviour" the night before his crime.

He had brutally woken her up, saying he had heard voices, before going to work, she reportedly told police.

France's police force have suffered a fresh blow after the killing of four colleagues by a staffer at Pars headquarters Credit: Marc Piasecki /Getty Images Europe More

Harcourt had converted to Islam about 18 months ago but police have thus far found no evidence his crime was driven by radical religious ideology.

Currently, anti-terror prosecutors are not involved in the murder investigation, according to government spokeswoman Sibeth Ndiaye.

Police said Harcourt had worked there since 2003 and was a well-respected if taciturn member of staff until Thursday, when he committed the deadliest attack in police headquarters since the liberation of Paris at the end of the Second World War, according to Le Monde.

He and his wife, who also has a serious hearing impairment, communicated via sign language. According to BFMTV, Harcourt had been frustrated at work at not being promoted and had for several months requested a sign language interpreter in the hope of moving to a network design post - to no avail.

Interior minister Christophe Castaner said the assailant had "never shown any behavioural problems".

Thursday's killings came a day after thousands of police officers staged a "march of anger" in Paris over working conditions, low morale and suicides. They say they have been stretched to the limit after months of containing weekly "yellow vest" anti-government demonstrations, and years of high alert following a string of terror attacks in France.
